questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of white discharge from her nipples for 4 months. During this period, menses have occurred at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals and have lasted 3 to 10 days; menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow. She has also had recurrent headaches that partially subside with ibuprofen. She has a healthy 5-year-old son. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Breast examination shows bilateral milklike discharge from the nipples; no masses are felt. Pelvic examination shows mild vaginal atrophy. An MRI of the head with contrast followed by hormone assays confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High levels of prolactin suppress the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus resulting in low levels of LH and FSH, and subsequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient likely has low estrogen levels, and estrogen replacement therapy (ERT) would improve her vaginal atrophy. However, ERT does not help to treat the underlying cause of her hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in asymptomatic patients with nonsecretory pituitary microadenomas. However, this patient has headaches, galactorrhea, irregular menses, and vaginal atrophy and should receive treatment. Without proper treatment, she is at risk of developing osteoporosis and infertility due to long-term suppression of sex hormone production. Also, further tumor growth may lead to bitemporal hemianopia or the destruction of normal pituitary gland tissue and deficiency of other pituitary hormones.

C) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the first-line treatment for most pituitary macroadenomas. Prolactinomas of any size, however, usually respond well to a less aggressive treatment modality; surgical resection is only considered as a second-line treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Dopamine receptor agonists such as cabergoline or bromocriptine are first-line treatments for all prolactinomas. By decreasing prolactin secretion they improve symptoms due to hyperprolactinemia such as galactorrhea, irregular menses, or vaginal atrophy, all of which are seen in this patient. Dopamine agonists usually also induce regression of tumor size, thereby improving symptoms due to mass effects such as headaches or bitemporal hemianopsia.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

External beam radiotherapy can be used to treat prolactinomas or other pituitary adenomas that do not respond to medical therapy or cannot be resected surgically. In this patient with likely prolactinoma, other treatment options should be tried first.
questions.hint: This patient's galactorrhea, irregular menses, vaginal atrophy, and confirmatory hormone assays indicate hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches and positive findings on MRI (likely an intrasellar mass) suggest a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma (i.e., prolactinoma).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of persistent headaches for the last 2 months. The symptoms started insidiously. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband but reports decreased interest in sexual intercourse over the past few months. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A pelvic ultrasound shows atrophic endometrium. A cranial MRI with contrast shows a 2-cm intrasellar mass. A hormone assay confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is a second-line treatment for prolactinoma that is only indicated if conservative treatment fails.

B) CORRECT:

Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist, is the first-line treatment for symptomatic prolactinoma regardless of tumor size. Dopamine agonists inhibit the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary gland, leading to decreased symptoms of hyperprolactinemia and a reduction in tumor size. Treatment for prolactinoma is indicated in all symptomatic patients (e.g., those with galactorrhea, hypogonadism) or in patients with existing or impending signs of mass effect (e.g., visual impairments, headaches).

Because bromocriptine is more likely to cause side effects (e.g., nausea) and is less effective than cabergoline, it is the second-line treatment for prolactinoma. Surgery may only be considered in patients for whom pharmacological treatment has been unsuccessful or cannot be tolerated.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy is sometimes used as adjuvant therapy for prolactinoma after surgical treatment, but would not be used as a first-line treatment for prolactinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Observation and monitoring are indicated for asymptomatic, nonsecretory pituitary adenomas and can also be considered in small, asymptomatic prolactinomas (microadenomas). However, since this patient is symptomatic (headache, amenorrhea, decreased libido), treatment is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Domperidone therapy exacerbates the symptoms of prolactinoma because this dopamine antagonist decreases the inhibiting role of dopamine on prolactin release, thereby further worsening hyperprolactinemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Biopsy is an invasive procedure that is rarely used to assess intrasellar masses because most masses can be diagnosed with hormonal and clinical assessment. If a biopsy is indicated, a resection of the entire mass is likely to be necessary. Because this patient's diagnosis is confirmed, a biopsy is not required.
questions.hint: This patient presents with persistent headaches, decreased libido, atrophic endometrium, and secondary amenorrhea, all of which suggest a pituitary adenoma. The intrasellar mass seen on the cranial MRI and a positive hormone assay confirm the suspected diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased sexual arousal and erectile dysfunction that has put a strain on his marriage for the last year. He has also had fatigue and generalized weakness for the past 9 months. He has noticed his bowel movements have not been as frequent as usual. He has an occasional dry cough and headaches. One year ago, he traveled to South Africa with his wife. He looks fatigued. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry skin and sparse pubic hair. Neurological examination reveals delayed deep tendon reflexes. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL


Platelet count
380,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

130 mEq/L


 Cl-

97 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 HCO3-

25 mEq/L


 Glucose
90 mg/dL


 TSH

0.2 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron overload from hemochromatosis can result in pituitary damage, leading to secondary hypothyroidism. While affected individuals also have other signs of classic pituitary dysfunction such as hypogonadism, they often also present with hyperglycemia and hyperpigmentation (bronze diabetes), and joint pain (MCP II and III).

B) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, tuberculosis (TB) can infiltrate the pituitary or the hypothalamus, causing secondary hypothyroidism. However, except for an occasional cough, this patient lacks findings of TB such as night sweats and weight loss. Even when traveling to countries where TB is endemic, significant exposure to high-risk populations (e.g., hospital workers) is required for infection.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests multiple hormonal deficiencies (although there is a considerable overlap in terms of the symptoms each hormonal deficiency can cause): constipation, dry skin, delayed deep tendon reflexes, bradycardia, and decreased TSH levels indicate secondary hypothyroidism; sparse pubic hair, and sexual dysfunction raise concern for hypogonadism; hyponatremia can result from adrenal insufficiency. In combination with headaches, these findings suggest a pituitary adenoma, which can compress the pituitary gland and lead to the destruction of hormone-producing cells (e.g., thyrotropic cells).

Pituitary hormones and the functions that depend on them are usually lost in the following order (from early to late): GH, LH/FSH, TSH, and ACTH.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Graves disease have low TSH levels but present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism such as heat intolerance, diarrhea, and warm and moist skin. Other hallmark signs are Graves ophthalmopathy and diffuse goiter, neither of which is present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with signs of hypothyroidism, since autoantibodies gradually destroy the thyroid gland and subsequently reduce thyroid hormone levels. Reactive TSH secretion by an intact pituitary follows, resulting in elevated rather than decreased TSH levels.
questions.hint: Decreased levels of TSH are consistent with secondary hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of frequent headaches and blurry vision during the past 4 months. He has also had difficulties achieving an erection over the past few weeks. Physical examination shows a temporal visual field deficit bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows an intrasellar mass. The mass is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyrotroph cells are TSH-secreting cells in the pituitary gland. Thyrotropic adenomas are very rare and only comprise 1% of all pituitary adenomas. They can cause secondary hyperthyroidism with symptoms like heat intolerance, weight loss, diarrhea, tachycardia, fine tremor, and muscle weakness, none of which are present in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Lactotroph cells are prolactin-producing cells in the pituitary gland. Prolactinomas account for nearly 80% of hormone-producing pituitary adenomas and 40–50% of all pituitary adenomas. This patient's erectile dysfunction is a common symptom of pathologically increased prolactin levels. Other symptoms include loss of libido, as well as gynecomastia in men and galactorrhea, amenorrhea and infertility in women.

C) INCORRECT:

Somatotroph cells are growth hormone-secreting cells in the pituitary gland. Somatotroph adenomas account for about 15% of all pituitary adenomas. Constantly increased levels of GH can lead to acromegaly, which this patient does not have. Erectile dysfunction is not caused by somatotroph adenomas.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonadotroph cells are LH- and FSH-producing cells in the pituitary gland. Gonadotropinomas are usually nonsecretory pituitary adenomas that do not cause increased hormone levels. They account for about 35% of all pituitary adenomas and make up 80–90% of nonsecretory pituitary adenomas. Depending on their size, they can cause symptoms of hypopituitarism via destruction of functioning pituitary cells. This patient does not express signs of hypopituitarism like secondary adrenal insufficiency, secondary hypothyroidism or central diabetes insipidus.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticotroph cells are ACTH-secreting cells in the pituitary gland. Corticotropinomas only account for about 5% of all pituitary adenomas. Increased ACTH production causes a secondary hypercortisolism through stimulation of the adrenal cortex, also called Cushing disease. The most common symptoms are central obesity, moon facies, buffalo hump, hypertension, osteoporosis, muscle atrophy, hirsutism and thin and easily bruisable skin, none of which are present in this patient.
questions.hint: Headaches and bitemporal hemianopia (due to pressure on the optic chiasm) in this patient with a sellar mass are highly suggestive of a pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman with subclinical hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches, loss of peripheral vision, and irregular menses. Her menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow, but her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She also reports that her interest in sexual intercourse has recently decreased. Her serum prolactin level is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline are the preferred pharmacotherapy for prolactinomas. These drugs act by increasing tonic dopamine signaling to inhibit lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary. This suppresses prolactin secretion and induces tumor shrinkage. Treatment for prolactinoma is indicated in cases such as this one, when the patient is symptomatic (e.g., headache, visual change, hypogonadism) or if the clinician believes that symptoms are imminent.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Estrogen replacement (HRT) can reduce the symptoms associated with menopause (e.g., irregular menses, worsening headaches, decreased libido). While this patient does have these symptoms, menopause would not explain her elevated serum prolactin, and estrogen is not an appropriate treatment for a prolactinoma or hyperprolactinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and DOPA decarboxylase antagonist, which treats hypertension by decreasing sympathetic outflow to the heart, kidneys, and peripheral vasculature as well as decreasing the production of catecholamines (e.g., dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine). Dopamine normally inhibits prolactin production; therefore, methyldopa-induced suppression of dopamine production would further elevate serum prolactin levels and exacerbate the symptoms seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is both a dopamine receptor and serotonin receptor antagonist that is used as an antiemetic and to treat gastroparesis and migraines. Although migraines can be associated with hormonal changes and this patient has irregular menses, her progressively worsening headaches more likely result from increased ICP caused by her prolactinoma. Prolactinoma would not be treated by metoclopramide. Moreover, because dopamine ordinarily inhibits prolactin secretion, administering metoclopramide (a dopamine receptor antagonist) would worsen this patient's hyperprolactinemia.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's subclinical hypothyroidism could progress to a manifest hypothyroidism with decreased thyroxine feedback to inhibit the hypothalamic production of TRH. TRH stimulates the secretion of TSH and prolactin. TRH-induced hyperprolactinemia can manifest as secondary amenorrhea, which is seen in this patient. However, clinical hypothyroidism would manifest with other symptoms (e.g., cold intolerance, weight gain, decreased DTR) that are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with decreased libido, secondary amenorrhea, loss of vision, and hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches suggest a prolactinoma as the etiology.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of his tall stature. His father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; his mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. He is at the 99th percentile for height and 88th percentile for BMI. Examination shows pronounced sweat stains below the armpits and broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. His fasting serum glucose is 138 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 16 years. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Tumor of the posterior pituitary gland

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is caused by circulating anti-TSH receptor antibodies. Although the condition may cause tall stature in adolescents, it is not associated with hyperglycemia, prognathism, or frontal bossing. Moreover, other characteristic features, e.g., Graves ophthalmopathy, tachycardia, and goiter are absent in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Gigantism is most commonly caused by a benign growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. Growth hormone (GH) stimulates insulin-like growth factor 1 synthesis in the liver, which in turn promotes cell proliferation, especially of the bones and cartilage. Excess GH also has a diabetogenic effect, which explains the elevated serum glucose in this patient. The treatment of choice for gigantism is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoma resection.

Growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas can cause gigantism in children and adolescents and acromegaly in adults. Both conditions are managed surgically with transsphenoidal adenomectomy, or, if surgery is not possible, pharmacologically with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide).

C) INCORRECT:

Tumors of the posterior pituitary gland can lead to hypersecretion of oxytocin or vasopressin, the two hormones secreted by the posterior pituitary. Neither of these hormones would cause the increase in height, skeletal changes, or hyperglycemia that is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

McCune-Albright syndrome is caused by mosaic mutations in G-protein signaling. One of the findings associated with the condition is precocious puberty, which may lead to accelerated growth and increased height in adolescence. However, since this patient shows no other features of McCune-Albright syndrome (e.g., cafe-au-lait spots, fibrous dysplasia of bone with pathologic fractures), this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Exogenous anabolic steroid use during adolescence induces premature closure of the epiphyseal growth plates, which leads to stunted growth rather than the linear growth acceleration seen in this patient. Hyperglycemia is, in fact, a common side effect of steroids. However, endocrine symptoms such as gynecomastia or small testes would also be expected with anabolic steroid use. Moreover, anabolic steroids would not cause frontal bossing of the skull or prognathism.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutated growth hormone receptors can be seen in children with idiopathic short stature or dwarfism. However, this patient presents with tall stature and increased linear bone growth.
questions.hint: Tall stature (> 97th percentile for age and sex), excessive sweating, broad hands and feet, frontal bossing, and prognathism (protrusion of the mandible) make gigantism the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her period for 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. A home pregnancy test was negative. She also reports recurrent headaches and has noticed that when she goes to the movies she cannot see the outer edges of the screen without turning her head to each side. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by abnormal growth of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abnormal growth of astrocytes is the underlying pathology of astrocytomas. While low-grade astrocytomas commonly manifest during childhood with a benign course, high-grade astrocytomas (e.g., glioblastoma multiforme) occurs in older individuals and manifests in rapidly progressive symptoms that depend upon the location of the lesion but may include headaches. This patient's prolonged course of symptoms and secondary amenorrhea is not suggestive of glioblastoma multiforme.

B) CORRECT:

Abnormal growth of the adenohypophysis is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms, which are consistent with a pituitary adenoma. Adenomas of the pituitary gland are most commonly due to aberrant proliferation of lactotroph cells in the adenohypophysis. The resulting hyperprolactinemia eventually causes suppression of gonadotropins and subsequent secondary amenorrhea. Bitemporal hemianopsia (due to compression of the optic chiasm) and headaches may develop as the adenoma grows.

Her symptoms could also be explained by a large nonsecreting pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm (bitemporal hemianopsia) and the pituitary stalk or the gonadotropic cells (secondary amenorrhea), but the absence of other symptoms of hypopituitarism makes prolactinoma more likely.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Abnormal growth of arachnoid cap cells is the underlying pathology of meningiomas. Even though this patient's recurrent headaches could be attributed to a meningioma, this tumor would not explain this patient's secondary amenorrhea or her visual disturbances.

D) INCORRECT:

Abnormal growth of ependymal cells is the underlying pathology of ependymomas, most of which arise close to the fourth ventricle. Ependymomas commonly cause obstructive hydrocephalus, which may manifest as recurrent headaches. However, ependymomas typically develop during childhood and are not associated with menstrual irregularities or visual disturbances.

E) INCORRECT:

Abnormal growth of Schwann cells leads to the development of a schwannoma, which typically arises near the cerebellopontine angle. Large tumors may lead to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, e.g., recurrent headache. However, in the case of a schwannoma, other features would likely be present, including tinnitus, vertigo, and hearing loss. Moreover, menstrual irregularities or bitemporal hemianopia would not be expected in the case of a Schwannoma.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

F) INCORRECT:

Abnormal growth of the pineal gland leads to the development of a pinealoma, which generally manifests during childhood. Symptoms of pinealomas include visual disturbances and dizziness or recurrent headaches (due to hydrocephalus). However, pinealomas are associated with vertical gaze palsy rather than the bitemporal hemianopsia observed in this patient. Moreover, menstrual disturbances would not be expected, as pinealomas are hormonally inactive.
questions.hint: A cranial contrast MRI would reveal an intrasellar mass.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent headaches. They have been getting progressively worse and no longer respond to ibuprofen. He also reports weight gain and excessive sweating. Physical examination shows prominent supraorbital ridges, prognathism, macroglossia with thick lips, and disproportionately broad hands and feet. There is decreased peripheral vision bilaterally on visual field testing. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the sella turcica. Genetic analysis of a biopsy specimen from the mass shows cells that overexpress adenylyl cyclase. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methimazole inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and can be used to treat thyrotropic adenomas of the pituitary. However, this patient does not have features of elevated thyroid hormone levels, such as weight loss and diarrhea. Methimazole is not used for the treatment of acromegaly.

B) CORRECT:

Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) inhibit the release of GH and they are the pharmacotherapy of choice for acromegaly if transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is not an option. The prolonged excess of both growth hormone and IGF-1 (which is secreted from the liver in response to elevated GH) results in the overgrowth of bone, cartilage, and other connective tissues, resulting in the characteristic findings of skin thickening, enlarged jaw (macrognathia), coarse facial features, and broad hands and feet. In children, excess GH secretion results in linear growth as well, but this is not seen in adults due to the fusion of the long bone epiphyses.

Other pharmacologic options for the treatment of acromegaly include dopamine agonists such as cabergoline or GH-receptor antagonists such as pegvisomant.

C) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that has an antagonistic effect when given continuously and is used to treat prostate cancer, endometriosis, and precocious puberty. It would not be of use in the treatment of a pituitary tumor, as GnRH is released by the hypothalamus.

D) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is a dopamine antagonist used for the treatment of schizophrenia. Dopamine agonists, such as cabergoline, may be used as an adjunctive or second-line treatment for acromegaly but a dopamine antagonist would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone inhibits cortisol synthesis and is used in the treatment of Cushing disease, which may be caused by an ACTH-producing pituitary tumor and could also cause weight gain and excessive sweating. However, this patient would be expected to have other features of Cushing disease, such as hirsutism, bruisable skin, and secondary hypertension. Metyrapone is not used for the treatment of acromegaly.
questions.hint: Refractory headaches, bitemporal hemianopsia, and a mass in the sella turcica are consistent with a pituitary adenoma, which can secrete growth hormone (GH) and result in the features of acromegaly present here (e.g., prognathism, prominent supraorbital ridges, macroglossia).

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to the physician for an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. Examination shows enlargement of the nose, forehead, and jaw as well as the hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 225 mg/dL. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 concentration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low serum GH can be seen in a number of conditions, e.g., following brain surgery, severe head injury, infection, or in patients with pituitary tumors. Although this patient's clinical symptoms (headache and bitemporal hemianopsia) suggest local mass effect in the pituitary, he also presents with features of acromegaly, which is classically associated with excess serum GH.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated urine cortisol levels are a typical finding in Cushing syndrome, which is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenoma can result in bitemporal hemianopsia and Cushing syndrome can manifest with hyperglycemia. However, other features of Cushing syndrome include proximal muscle weakness, central obesity, and abdominal striae, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Low insulin levels are seen in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, in which pancreatic beta cells are destroyed, resulting in persistently elevated serum glucose levels. This patient's hyperglycemia is instead due to the endocrinopathy of acromegaly, in which excess growth hormone (GH) levels stimulate gluconeogenesis, causing a state of insulin resistance. Hyperglycemia then induces compensatory hyperinsulinemia; therefore, elevated serum insulin levels would be expected in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Low urine osmolality is typical in patients with diabetes insipidus, which can occur secondary to brain tumors. Though this patient presents with features suggestive of a local mass effect from the pituitary, he does not have symptoms of diabetes insipidus, such as polyuria, nocturia, or polydipsia.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) can result from prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas, which can also cause bitemporal hemianopsia and headache, both of which are seen here. In men, symptoms of prolactinoma typically include gynecomastia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (presenting with erectile dysfunction and loss of libido). Elevated prolactin is rarely seen in individuals with acromegaly, such as this man. In addition, he lacks classic symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, making a different finding more likely.

F) CORRECT:

An elevated serum IGF-1 concentration is the most likely finding for this patient with acromegaly, a condition most commonly caused by a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Excess secretion of GH stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn stimulates cell growth and proliferation while inhibiting apoptosis. IGF-1 is part of the negative feedback cycle that governs normal GH production, so IGF-1 levels are high in response to the pathologically elevated GH levels.

IGF-1 is the most reliable indicator of acromegaly and measurement of IGF-1 levels is the first step in diagnosing patients with suspected acromegaly. Normal levels of IGF-1 rule out acromegaly as a diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acromegaly (hypertension, coarsened and enlarged features, hyperglycemia). His headache and bitemporal hemianopsia indicate local mass effect.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman recently diagnosed with a prolactin-producing pituitary macroadenoma is treated with cabergoline for several weeks and presents with a one-week history of nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. She has had a headache for 2 days that has progressively worsened. She reports not having any neck pain, rash, or fever.
On her last hospital visit, the patient had a prolactin level of 534 ng/mL (reference range, 0–20), but her other pituitary-axis laboratory tests were within the normal range.
In the emergency department today, her blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg, her heart rate is 115 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air. On physical examination, she is lethargic and has dry mucous membranes. Her pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her extraocular-muscle function is not intact, and there is a weakness in abduction in the right eye. Her neck is supple with no apparent thyromegaly. Her abdomen is soft.
CT of her head shows a grossly unchanged pituitary macroadenoma. No acute intracranial process is seen. Abdominal ultrasonography of the gallbladder, liver, and kidneys is unremarkable. A urine pregnancy test is negative.
A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal. Her endocrine laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
0.5
0.5–4.7


Free thyroxine (ng/dL)
0.9
0.8–1.8


Prolactin (ng/mL)
32
0–20


Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s prolactin level is not normal, additional dopaminergic medication, such as bromocriptine, is unlikely to be helpful given that she is already being treated with cabergoline.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI and lumbar puncture are helpful diagnostic tools for a patient with headache and cranial-nerve palsy, the patient’s condition should be stabilized first.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms suggest pituitary apoplexy, which results from a sudden infarction or hemorrhage in the pituitary gland. Pituitary apoplexy usually occurs in the setting of a preexisting pituitary tumor but can also occur in normal pituitary glands. Depending on the area involved, the clinical presentation can vary from headaches to visual disturbances to coma.

CT of the head can identify an early hemorrhage, but it can miss many subacute or subtle infarcts.

Patients with pituitary apoplexy can have acute pituitary dysfunction, such as adrenal insufficiency, growth-hormone deficiency, or central hypothyroidism. The most important endocrine dysfunction is central adrenal deficiency, which can lead to adrenal crisis. To prevent this, stress-dose hydrocortisone treatment should be given promptly.

Key learning point: The most important step in managing suspected pituitary apoplexy is administration of hydrocortisone.

D) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin should not be started in an acute setting in the absence of obvious central diabetes insipidus.

E) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine should not be given before glucocorticoids, as it can induce adrenal crisis in a patient who has adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents for follow-up 6 weeks after being hospitalized for urosepsis with hemodynamic instability. During this hospitalization, she underwent thyroid function testing because of persistent tachycardia and was found to have a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.15 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), a normal free thyroxine level, and a total triiodothyronine level of 57 ng/dL (60–181).
At today’s visit, she has recovered from the sepsis, is asymptomatic, and has a normal heart rate. Repeat thyroid function test results are normal, but a lingering concern for central hypothyroidism (given the initial test results) prompts measurement of the other pituitary hormone levels. Cortisol, adrenocorticotropic hormone, insulin-like growth factor-1, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and estradiol levels are all found to be normal, but the prolactin level is elevated at 83 ng/mL (reference range, 0–20), confirmed with a repeat measurement of 96 ng/mL.
On further questioning, the patient reports having regular menstrual cycles since menarche and conceiving two children with no difficulty. She reports no headaches, visual disturbances, or milky discharge from her breasts. Her only medication is over-the-counter ferrous sulfate.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s elevated prolactin concentration?

choices.text: Remeasure prolactin using serial dilutions of the serum
Reassure the patient without any further evaluation
Obtain MRI of the brain (with pituitary protocol)

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s thyroid function test results and clinical presentation are most consistent with euthyroid sick syndrome, a transient central hypothyroid state that is a normal physiologic response to an extreme physiological stressor such as sepsis. Patients with suspected euthyroid sick syndrome should undergo repeat thyroid function tests several weeks after they have recovered from their initial illness; in most cases, the test results are normal, and further evaluation for pituitary pathology is not indicated.

In this case, the patient’s repeat thyroid function test results were normal, so additional pituitary testing was not clearly indicated. However, the additional testing led to the incidental discovery of an elevated prolactin level. Given that this patient has no signs or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia or a prolactinoma, the most likely reason for the prolactin elevation is the presence of macroprolactin.

Macroprolactin — a large molecule (150–200 kDa) compared with monomeric prolactin (23 kDa) — typically consists of prolactin bound to immunoglobulin G. It is detected by most prolactin assays and, given its slower clearance from circulation, is present at higher serum levels than prolactin; it can therefore cause an elevation in prolactin levels. Macroprolactin is estimated to be present in 10% to 20% of people with elevated prolactin levels. Because this molecule is biologically inactive, it does not cause any symptoms. Thus, in patients who have elevated prolactin levels without any other signs or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, the presence of macroprolactin should be evaluated.

Key learning point: The presence of macroprolactin can lead to elevations in measured prolactin levels without any clinical signs or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring prolactin levels after serial dilutions of serum is a way to evaluate for the hook effect — a laboratory artifact whereby very high concentrations of serum prolactin saturate the antibodies in a sandwich immunoassay, resulting in a measured prolactin concentration that appears to be only modestly elevated. This artifact can result in misdiagnosis and should be suspected when a patient with significant symptoms of hyperprolactinemia and a pituitary macroadenoma on imaging is found to have only a modestly elevated prolactin concentration. The hook effect can be avoided by requesting that the laboratory perform serial dilutions, but this would not be indicated for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s thyroid function test results and clinical presentation are most consistent with euthyroid sick syndrome, a transient central hypothyroid state that is a normal physiologic response to an extreme physiological stressor such as sepsis. Patients with suspected euthyroid sick syndrome should undergo repeat thyroid function tests several weeks after they have recovered from their initial illness; in most cases, the test results are normal, and further evaluation for pituitary pathology is not indicated.

In this case, the patient’s repeat thyroid function test results were normal, so additional pituitary testing was not clearly indicated. However, the additional testing led to the incidental discovery of an elevated prolactin level. Given that this patient has no signs or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia or a prolactinoma, the most likely reason for the prolactin elevation is the presence of macroprolactin. Because this molecule is biologically inactive, it does not cause any symptoms. Thus, in patients who have elevated prolactin levels without any other signs or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, the presence of macroprolactin should be evaluated.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an MRI of the pituitary gland or treating this patient with cabergoline would be premature, as the patient should first be evaluated for macroprolactinemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an MRI of the pituitary gland or treating this patient with cabergoline would be premature, as the patient should first be evaluated for macroprolactinemia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with a history of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) presents for routine follow-up. He was diagnosed with ALL at age 4 and received induction chemotherapy followed by craniospinal radiotherapy (to prevent leukemic involvement of the central nervous system). His radiation dose was approximately 20 Gy. He then received consolidation and maintenance chemotherapy. He has not had any evidence of recurrent disease and has not been diagnosed with any complications of his cancer therapy.
He appears well, his vital signs are normal, and both a detailed review of symptoms and a detailed physical examination are unremarkable. His height is as expected, given the height of his parents.
Which one of the following monitoring strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Annual measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone, free thyroxine, and free triiodothyronine
Annual history and physical examination focused on endocrine dysfunction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a history of childhood radiation involving the neck are at risk for both structural thyroid disease (nodules and cancer) and functional thyroid disease (primarily hypothyroidism). Patients with neck radiation exposure ≥25 Gy should undergo annual testing for thyroid dysfunction, whereas patients with <25 Gy of radiation exposure (as in this case) require testing only if they have signs or symptoms of thyroid dysfunction or if they are considering pregnancy. Testing usually consists of measuring the TSH level. However, in patients with suspected hypothalamic-pituitary pathology, a total or free T4 level must also be measured, to avoid missing central hypothyroidism with measurement of TSH alone. A free triiodothyronine measurement is never necessary in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

Bone mineral density measurement can be considered (if it has not been previously obtained) in patients with additional risk factors such as substantial glucocorticoid exposures, hypogonadism, or growth-hormone deficiency. Annual follow-up measurement is rarely necessary; the frequency of follow-up is usually every 2 to 10 years depending on the findings at baseline.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening for thyroid nodules and cancer should, at a minimum, consist of regular examination of the thyroid gland and cervical lymph nodes, with an assessment of symptoms such as neck mass or swelling, dysphagia, and voice changes. The use of screening thyroid ultrasound is controversial, given the likelihood of detecting clinically insignificant thyroid nodules and the associated cost and patient anxiety. Any decision to conduct a screening thyroid ultrasound in the absence of a clinically detected thyroid mass should be a shared decision with the patient. Even if the patient opts for screening ultrasound, it should not be repeated annually; although the optimal frequency is unknown, most experts wait 3 to 5 years before repeating a thyroid ultrasound after a normal result.

D) INCORRECT:

Pituitary-specific imaging is unnecessary in this scenario.

E) CORRECT:

Childhood cancer survivors require unique long-term monitoring for potential adverse effects related to their cancer therapy, including endocrine effects. Up to 50% of survivors will develop an endocrine disorder. Adults treated with radiation during childhood, including those with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, are at risk for developing the following endocrine conditions:

• Hypogonadism (primary and secondary) with reduced fertility, symptoms of estrogen or testosterone deficiency, reduced bone mineral density, and bone fractures
• Hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction following cranial irradiation (especially in patients who received radiation doses ≥30 Gy)
• Thyroid dysfunction (both primary hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism) following neck radiation
• Thyroid nodules and thyroid cancer following head or neck radiation

All survivors of childhood cancer should have an annual history and physical examination with a focus on signs and symptoms associated with hypopituitarism, thyroid dysfunction, and hypogonadism. Such signs and symptoms include menstrual irregularity, low libido, erectile dysfunction, fatigue, constipation, skin and hair changes, light-headedness, and unintentional weight change.

In patients exposed to ≥30 Gy of hypothalamic-pituitary radiation, routine laboratory screening with pituitary blood tests (growth hormone, insulin-like growth factor-1, luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, testosterone or estradiol, 8 a.m. adrenocorticotropic hormone and cortisol, thyroid-stimulating hormone [TSH], and free thyroxine [T4]) is recommended as frequently as once a year.

In patients exposed to <30 Gy of hypothalamic-pituitary radiation (as in this case), routine laboratory screening is not needed, but if the patient experiences any symptoms, appropriate pituitary laboratory tests can be sent. Measurement of prolactin levels is not routinely indicated as a screening test in any survivor of childhood cancer because hyperprolactinemia is unusual; a prolactin level can be measured if the patient has relevant symptoms or signs (e.g., hypogonadism, galactorrhea).

Key learning point: Patients with a history of craniospinal radiation for childhood cancer should have an annual history and physical examination, with subsequent pertinent laboratory testing.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She works as a librarian and has noticed that she has been bumping into the bookshelves more often recently. Today, she did not see a parked car, which resulted in the auto collision. She generally feels well. Review of symptoms is unremarkable except for intermittent headaches. She is not sexually active and has had regular menstrual cycles every month until recently; her last menstrual period was 7 months ago. A pregnancy test is negative.
Ophthalmologic examination reveals normal visual acuity (20/20 vision). Extraocular muscle movements are intact. There is no conjunctival injection. Bitemporal hemianopsia is noted on bedside visual field testing. Otherwise, the neurologic examination is normal.
What is the most likely site of the lesion causing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lesions of occipital and parietal lobes can manifest with homonymous (not bitemporal) visual defects, depending on the location.

B) CORRECT:

Bitemporal hemianopsia, or loss of the temporal visual field of both eyes, is usually caused by a lesion in the sella turcica.

The most common cause of a mass in the sella turcica is a pituitary adenoma. Some pituitary adenomas secrete functional hormones and manifest because of hormonal hyperfunctioning, such as adrenocorticotropic hormone secretion (leading to Cushing disease) or growth-hormone secretion (leading to acromegaly). Nonfunctioning pituitary adenomas do not secrete any functional hormones and, therefore, tend to cause symptoms that are related to their size. Examples of such symptoms include headaches; pituitary hormone deficiencies (most commonly hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, leading to amenorrhea or low testosterone levels) from compression of normal, nonadenomatous pituitary cells; or bitemporal hemianopsia related to suprasellar tumor extension with compression of the optic chiasm.

Key learning point: Bitemporal hemianopsia is usually caused by a lesion located in the sella turcica.
Image Description:

(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

C) INCORRECT:

A lesion of the optic nerve will cause vision loss only in the affected eye.

D) INCORRECT:

Lesions affecting the cavernous sinus may cause cranial nerve palsies, such as third-nerve palsy, but would not cause bitemporal hemianopsia.

E) INCORRECT:

Lesions of occipital and parietal lobes can manifest with homonymous (not bitemporal) visual defects, depending on the location.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-month history of intermittent headaches. They have been getting progressively worse and no longer respond to ibuprofen. He also reports weight gain and excessive sweating. Physical examination shows prominent supraorbital ridges, prognathism, macroglossia with thick lips, and disproportionately broad hands and feet. There is decreased peripheral vision bilaterally on visual field testing. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the sella turcica. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methimazole inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and can be used to treat thyrotropic adenomas of the pituitary. However, this patient does not have features of elevated thyroid hormone levels, such as weight loss and diarrhea. Methimazole is not used for the treatment of acromegaly.

B) CORRECT:

Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) inhibit the release of GH and they are the pharmacotherapy of choice for acromegaly if transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is not an option. The prolonged excess of both growth hormone and IGF-1 (which is secreted from the liver in response to elevated GH) results in the overgrowth of bone, cartilage, and other connective tissues, resulting in the characteristic findings of skin thickening, enlarged jaw (macrognathia), coarse facial features, and broad hands and feet. In children, excess GH secretion results in linear growth as well, but this is not seen in adults due to the fusion of the long bone epiphyses.

Other pharmacologic options for the treatment of acromegaly include dopamine agonists such as cabergoline or GH-receptor antagonists such as pegvisomant.

C) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that has an antagonistic effect when given continuously and is used to treat prostate cancer, endometriosis, and precocious puberty. It would not be of use in the treatment of a pituitary tumor, as GnRH is released by the hypothalamus.

D) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is a dopamine antagonist used for the treatment of schizophrenia. Dopamine agonists, such as cabergoline, may be used as an adjunctive or second-line treatment for acromegaly but a dopamine antagonist would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone inhibits cortisol synthesis and is used in the treatment of Cushing disease, which may be caused by an ACTH-producing pituitary tumor and could also cause weight gain and excessive sweating. However, this patient would be expected to have other features of Cushing disease, such as hirsutism, bruisable skin, and secondary hypertension. Metyrapone is not used for the treatment of acromegaly.
questions.hint: Refractory headaches, bitemporal hemianopsia, and a mass in the sella turcica are consistent with a pituitary adenoma, which can secrete growth hormone (GH) and result in the features of acromegaly present here (e.g., prognathism, prominent supraorbital ridges, macroglossia).

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to the office for an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. Examination shows enlargement of the nose, forehead, and jaw as well as the hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 225 mg/dL. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 concentration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low serum GH can be seen in a number of conditions, e.g., following brain surgery, severe head injury, infection, or in patients with pituitary tumors. Although this patient's clinical symptoms (headache and bitemporal hemianopsia) suggest local mass effect in the pituitary, he also presents with features of acromegaly, which is classically associated with excess serum GH.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated urine cortisol levels are a typical finding in Cushing syndrome, which is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenoma can result in bitemporal hemianopsia and Cushing syndrome can manifest with hyperglycemia. However, other features of Cushing syndrome include proximal muscle weakness, central obesity, and abdominal striae, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Low insulin levels are seen in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, in which pancreatic beta cells are destroyed, resulting in persistently elevated serum glucose levels. This patient's hyperglycemia is instead due to the endocrinopathy of acromegaly, in which excess growth hormone (GH) levels stimulate gluconeogenesis, causing a state of insulin resistance. Hyperglycemia then induces compensatory hyperinsulinemia; therefore, elevated serum insulin levels would be expected in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) can result from prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas, which can also cause bitemporal hemianopsia and headache, both of which are seen here. In men, symptoms of prolactinoma typically include gynecomastia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (presenting with erectile dysfunction and loss of libido). Elevated prolactin is rarely seen in individuals with acromegaly, such as this man. In addition, he lacks classic symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, making a different finding more likely.

E) CORRECT:

An elevated serum IGF-1 concentration is the most likely finding for this patient with acromegaly, a condition most commonly caused by a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Excess secretion of GH stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn stimulates cell growth and proliferation while inhibiting apoptosis. IGF-1 is part of the negative feedback cycle that governs normal GH production, so IGF-1 levels are high in response to the pathologically elevated GH levels.

IGF-1 is the most reliable indicator of acromegaly and measurement of IGF-1 levels is the first step in diagnosing patients with suspected acromegaly. Normal levels of IGF-1 rule out acromegaly as a diagnosis.

Key learning point: Acromegaly is best diagnosed by elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels, which reflect excess growth hormone activity.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acromegaly (hypertension, coarsened and enlarged features, hyperglycemia). His headache and bitemporal hemianopsia indicate local mass effect.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of decreased sexual arousal and erectile dysfunction. He has also had fatigue and generalized weakness for the past 9 months. He has noticed his bowel movements have not been as frequent as usual. He has frequent headaches. He looks fatigued. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry skin and sparse pubic hair. Neurological examination reveals delayed deep tendon reflexes. Serum studies show:


Na+

130 mEq/L


Cl-

97 mEq/L


K+

4.5 mEq/L


HCO3-

25 mEq/L


Glucose
90 mg/dL


TSH
0.2 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron overload from hemochromatosis can result in pituitary damage, leading to secondary hypothyroidism. While affected individuals also have other signs of classic pituitary dysfunction such as hypogonadism, they often also present with hyperglycemia and hyperpigmentation (bronze diabetes), and joint pain (MCP II and III).

B) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, tuberculosis (TB) can infiltrate the pituitary or the hypothalamus, causing secondary hypothyroidism. However, except for an occasional cough, this patient lacks findings of TB such as night sweats and weight loss. Even when traveling to countries where TB is endemic, significant exposure to high-risk populations (e.g., hospital workers) is required for infection.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests multiple hormonal deficiencies (although there is a considerable overlap in terms of the symptoms each hormonal deficiency can cause): constipation, dry skin, delayed deep tendon reflexes, bradycardia, and decreased TSH levels indicate secondary hypothyroidism; sparse pubic hair, and sexual dysfunction raise concern for hypogonadism; hyponatremia can result from adrenal insufficiency. In combination with headaches, these findings suggest a pituitary adenoma, which can compress the pituitary gland and lead to the destruction of hormone-producing cells (e.g., thyrotropic cells).

Pituitary hormones and the functions that depend on them are usually lost in the following order (from early to late): GH, LH/FSH, TSH, and ACTH.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Graves disease have low TSH levels but present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism such as heat intolerance, diarrhea, and warm and moist skin. Other hallmark signs are Graves ophthalmopathy and diffuse goiter, neither of which is present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with signs of hypothyroidism, since autoantibodies gradually destroy the thyroid gland and subsequently reduce thyroid hormone levels. Reactive TSH secretion by an intact pituitary follows, resulting in elevated rather than decreased TSH levels.
questions.hint: Decreased levels of TSH are consistent with secondary hypothyroidism.

(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

C) INCORRECT:

A lesion of the optic nerve will cause vision loss only in the affected eye.

D) INCORRECT:
