questions.text: A 34-year-old woman describes intermittent milky discharge from both breasts for the past 6 months. She also states that her menstrual cycle has become irregular during this time. She is sexually active and reports reduced libido. She has occasional headaches. On physical examination, she has bilateral milky discharge with minimal areolar pressure and no discernible breast mass. Bilateral temporal visual-field defects are noted on visual-field examination. Laboratory testing shows a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level, a normal free thyroxine level, and an elevated prolactin level. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A repeat fasting prolactin level remains elevated. Renal function is normal. MRI of the sella demonstrates an 18-mm sellar mass with suprasellar extension and compression of the optic chiasm, most consistent with a pituitary adenoma. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Begin an oral contraceptive containing estrogen and progesterone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the tumor is resistant to medical management, surgery may be necessary as second-line treatment, but this is relatively infrequent. Most patients who are considered resistant to dopamine agonist therapy have a partial response, meaning there is tumor shrinkage and the prolactin level decreases but does not normalize. In these cases, endoscopic transsphenoidal surgery may be necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

An oral contraceptive would not treat the underlying cause of this patient’s oligomenorrhea and would further impair her ability to conceive.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. Prolactinomas may manifest with galactorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or amenorrhea; decreased libido; erectile dysfunction; infertility; and osteopenia. Depending on the size of the prolactinoma, other symptoms may include headaches, visual-field disturbances, cranial-nerve palsies, symptoms of hypopituitarism, and, in rare cases, seizures or hydrocephalus. All patients with hyperprolactinemia of unclear etiology should undergo MRI to evaluate for a prolactinoma.

First-line treatment of prolactinoma is dopamine agonist therapy. Bromocriptine and cabergoline are both effective at quickly reducing the prolactin level and shrinking the tumor over time. Both medications are options in patients who are trying to achieve pregnancy, but the safest approach in the setting of optic-chiasm compression may be to defer pregnancy until the tumor has shrunk, to avoid progression of vision symptoms under the influence of the elevated estrogen levels that occur during pregnancy. Uncontrolled primary hypothyroidism can lead to hyperprolactinemia.

Key learning point: The initial management for a patient with hyperprolactinemia and evidence of a pituitary adenoma with optic-chiasm compression on sellar MRI is dopamine agonist therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic radiotherapy can reduce the size of a prolactinoma, but it can take years to achieve maximal effect, and hypopituitarism can occur. Radiotherapy is therefore reserved for rare cases of prolactinomas that cannot be managed medically or surgically.

E) INCORRECT:

If hypothyroidism is present, it should be corrected before treatment of hyperprolactinemia is initiated. In this case, the patient’s thyroid function was found to be normal, so treatment with levothyroxine would not be appropriate.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman with subclinical hypothyroidism comes to the office because of a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches, loss of peripheral vision, and irregular menses. Her menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow, but her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She also reports that her interest in sexual intercourse has recently decreased. Her serum prolactin level is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline are the preferred pharmacotherapy for prolactinomas. These drugs act by increasing tonic dopamine signaling to inhibit lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary. This suppresses prolactin secretion and induces tumor shrinkage. Treatment for prolactinoma is indicated in cases such as this one, when the patient is symptomatic (e.g., headache, visual change, hypogonadism) or if the clinician believes that symptoms are imminent.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Estrogen replacement (HRT) can reduce the symptoms associated with menopause (e.g., irregular menses, worsening headaches, decreased libido). While this patient does have these symptoms, menopause would not explain her elevated serum prolactin, and estrogen is not an appropriate treatment for a prolactinoma or hyperprolactinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and DOPA decarboxylase antagonist, which treats hypertension by decreasing sympathetic outflow to the heart, kidneys, and peripheral vasculature as well as decreasing the production of catecholamines (e.g., dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine). Dopamine normally inhibits prolactin production; therefore, methyldopa-induced suppression of dopamine production would further elevate serum prolactin levels and exacerbate the symptoms seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is both a dopamine receptor and serotonin receptor antagonist that is used as an antiemetic and to treat gastroparesis and migraines. Although migraines can be associated with hormonal changes and this patient has irregular menses, her progressively worsening headaches more likely result from increased ICP caused by her prolactinoma. Prolactinoma would not be treated by metoclopramide. Moreover, because dopamine ordinarily inhibits prolactin secretion, administering metoclopramide (a dopamine receptor antagonist) would worsen this patient's hyperprolactinemia.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's subclinical hypothyroidism could progress to a manifest hypothyroidism with decreased thyroxine feedback to inhibit the hypothalamic production of TRH. TRH stimulates the secretion of TSH and prolactin. TRH-induced hyperprolactinemia can manifest as secondary amenorrhea, which is seen in this patient. However, clinical hypothyroidism would manifest with other symptoms (e.g., cold intolerance, weight gain, decreased DTR) that are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with decreased libido, secondary amenorrhea, loss of vision, and hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches suggest a prolactinoma as the etiology.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman presents with six months of gradually worsening headaches and difficulty noticing objects to either side, causing her to bump into furniture. She also reports decreased libido and occasional clear fluid discharge from her breasts. Visual field testing shows loss of both temporal fields. An MRI is planned for further evaluation (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Prolactin
1250 pmol/L
< 870 pmol/L


Which diagnosis best explains this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas, benign tumors from Rathke’s pouch remnants, typically affect children or older adults. They can cause bitemporal hemianopsia and endocrine dysfunctions. However, the isolated hyperprolactinemia and specific endocrine symptoms in this patient suggest a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma rather than a craniopharyngioma.

B) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas can compress the optic chiasm, causing visual field loss. However, they do not secrete hormones. While they can cause elevated prolactin levels through the stalk effect, the specific endocrine symptoms here indicate a lesion directly affecting pituitary hormone regulation, which is not typical for meningiomas.

C) CORRECT:

Prolactinoma, a type of pituitary adenoma, can manifest with bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm by an expanding sellar mass. Elevated serum prolactin levels indicate a prolactin-secreting tumor, leading to symptoms such as decreased libido and galactorrhea. These symptoms result from suppressed gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, reducing gonadotropin levels and affecting reproductive function. The combination of visual field deficits, elevated prolactin, and reproductive symptoms supports the diagnosis of prolactinoma.

Key learning point: Pituitary adenomas, such as prolactinomas, can compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia, a common visual field defect characterized by loss of peripheral vision in both temporal fields.

D) INCORRECT:

Pituitary hemorrhage typically presents with sudden severe headache and rapid neurologic deterioration, unlike the gradual symptoms seen here. The chronic nature of the patient's symptoms, including modestly elevated prolactin levels and progressive visual deficits, suggests a slowly enlarging lesion rather than an acute hemorrhagic event.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of palpitations, weight loss, heat intolerance, and occasional insomnia to the clinic. She also reports a 2-month history of amenorrhea and new-onset bilateral galactorrhea. She denies headache or visual changes. Physical examination reveals a resting tremor, mild lid retraction, and no significant thyroid enlargement (see lab results).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
120/70 mmHg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
8.5 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
38 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L


Prolactin
45 μg/L
< 870 pmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is used for primary hyperthyroidism, where TSH is suppressed due to excess thyroid hormone production by the thyroid gland. This patient has elevated TSH and T4, indicating central hyperthyroidism, likely from a pituitary adenoma. Methimazole would not address the pituitary source of hormone excess.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid ultrasound evaluates thyroid morphology, such as nodules or enlargement, in primary thyroid disorders. The patient's elevated TSH and T4 suggest central hyperthyroidism, not a primary thyroid issue. The presence of galactorrhea and amenorrhea indicates a pituitary process, making thyroid ultrasound unnecessary.

C) CORRECT:

The elevated free thyroxine (T4) level with a non-suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suggests central hyperthyroidism, likely due to a pituitary adenoma. The patient's amenorrhea and galactorrhea, along with elevated prolactin, further support a pituitary lesion. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pituitary provides high-resolution imaging of the sellar region, essential for identifying and characterizing pituitary adenomas, such as TSH-secreting tumors, which can disrupt normal hormonal regulation.

Key learning point: In cases of secondary hyperthyroidism with elevated TSH and symptoms of galactorrhea and amenorrhea, a pituitary MRI is indicated to evaluate for a possible TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A radioactive iodine uptake scan differentiates causes of thyrotoxicosis in primary thyroid disorders, where TSH is suppressed. This patient has elevated TSH and T4, indicating a central cause. The scan does not assess pituitary lesions, which are suggested by the patient's hormonal profile and symptoms.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old office manager presents with progressively worsening headaches and blurring of peripheral vision for three months, occasionally leading to near-accidents while driving. Examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia on perimetry testing, but the fundoscopic exam is normal. The patient denies symptoms of active hormone hypersecretion or pituitary insufficiency beyond visual complaints, although he notes mild fatigue (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Cortisol 8 a.m.
400 nmol/L
138 - 635 nmol/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
12 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L


Growth hormone
5 ng/L
2 - 10 ng/L


Prolactin
950 pmol/L
< 870 pmol/L



MRI of the brain: 2.5-cm sellar mass with suprasellar extension compressing the optic chiasm
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is appropriate for small, asymptomatic microadenomas. However, this patient has significant compressive symptoms, including bitemporal hemianopia and a 2.5-cm sellar mass compressing the optic chiasm. The mildly elevated prolactin level suggests a stalk effect, not a secreting adenoma. Observation risks further tumor growth and irreversible visual damage.

B) CORRECT:

Pituitary macroadenomas causing compressive symptoms, such as bitemporal hemianopia, require surgical intervention to relieve optic chiasm compression. The 2.5-cm sellar mass with suprasellar extension compresses the optic chiasm, making trans-sphenoidal resection necessary to restore visual function and prevent further deterioration. The mildly elevated prolactin level likely results from the stalk effect, not a prolactinoma, and does not warrant medical therapy. The trans-sphenoidal approach provides direct access to the sellar region, allowing efficient tumor debulking while preserving adjacent structures.

Key learning point: In cases of pituitary macroadenoma with optic chiasm compression and visual field defects, trans-sphenoidal surgery is the definitive treatment to relieve the compression and address the mass effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic radiosurgery is used for small, residual, or recurrent adenomas, not for primary treatment of large masses with significant mass effect. It induces gradual tumor shrinkage, unsuitable for immediate decompression of the optic chiasm. The 2.5-cm lesion with visual deficits requires prompt surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose bromocriptine is used for prolactin-secreting adenomas, but the mildly elevated prolactin level here suggests a stalk effect, not a prolactinoma. The patient's visual deficits result from optic chiasm compression by the sellar mass, requiring surgical decompression. Bromocriptine would not provide the rapid relief needed for visual compromise.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of amenorrhea and occasional milky discharge from her breasts to the Outpatient Clinic. She reports mild headaches but no visual disturbances. She has never been pregnant, and her menarche was at age 12 with previously regular cycles. Examination shows no significant thyroid enlargement, and vital signs are stable. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Prolactin
1100 pmol/L
< 870 pmol/L


Follicle-stimulating hormone
3 IU/L
5-20 IU/L



MRI of the brain: 7-mm lesion in the pituitary gland
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's amenorrhea, galactorrhea, elevated prolactin level, and 7-mm pituitary lesion suggest a prolactinoma. Prolactinomas increase prolactin secretion, suppressing gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and reducing follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion, leading to menstrual irregularities. Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist, decreases prolactin secretion and promotes tumor shrinkage by stimulating D2 receptors on lactotroph cells. Its long half-life and tolerability make it the preferred treatment for prolactinomas without significant mass effects, normalizing prolactin levels and restoring the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

Key learning point: In cases of prolactinoma with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, the first-line treatment is a dopamine agonist like cabergoline to reduce prolactin levels and restore normal gonadal function.

B) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal resection is reserved for large pituitary adenomas causing mass effects or those unresponsive to medical therapy. The 7-mm lesion is a microadenoma, typically managed with dopamine agonists. Surgery carries risks like damage to normal pituitary tissue and cerebrospinal fluid leaks, which are avoidable with effective medical treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Estrogen supplementation does not address the underlying hyperprolactinemia, which suppresses GnRH and reduces FSH production. High prolactin levels inhibit GnRH release, leading to ovarian hypoestrogenism. Exogenous estrogen can increase prolactin secretion, exacerbating the condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Serial imaging is appropriate for incidental lesions without clinical or biochemical abnormalities. This patient has symptoms of hyperprolactinemia and elevated prolactin levels, indicating a functional lesion. Monitoring alone does not address hormonal abnormalities or symptoms, necessitating medical intervention.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of dull headaches and progressive difficulty seeing objects in her periphery. She also reports weight gain and occasional galactorrhea. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination shows no thyroid enlargement, but mild bilateral visual field deficits. Basic laboratory values demonstrate normal electrolytes (see report).
MRI of the brain: 1.8-cm lesion in the sellar region
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoids are used in acute pituitary apoplexy, characterized by sudden headache, vision loss, and adrenal insufficiency. This patient has a chronic presentation with galactorrhea and weight gain, indicating a functioning pituitary adenoma rather than an acute inflammatory condition.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with a pituitary macroadenoma, evaluating hormonal output is essential. Symptoms such as galactorrhea and weight gain suggest a functioning tumor, possibly prolactin-secreting. A comprehensive anterior pituitary hormone panel assesses prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), growth hormone (GH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH). This evaluation confirms hormone hypersecretion and identifies any pituitary function deficits due to compression. The results guide further management, including medical therapy with dopamine agonists or surgical intervention if necessary.

Key learning point: In the case of a pituitary macroadenoma, the initial step is to assess pituitary function with an anterior pituitary hormone profile to identify any hormonal imbalances.

C) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal surgery is reserved for nonfunctional adenomas or when medical therapy fails. In prolactin-secreting adenomas, dopamine agonists are first-line, effectively reducing prolactin levels and tumor size, alleviating symptoms like visual field deficits. Surgery is considered if medical management is ineffective or not tolerated.

D) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic radiosurgery is used for residual, recurrent, or inoperable pituitary tumors, not as initial treatment. It takes months to reduce tumor size and may risk damaging nearby structures like the optic chiasm. Medical therapy or surgical decompression is preferred for macroadenomas with compressive symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of intermittent headaches that have progressively worsened and are now unresponsive to ibuprofen. He also reports weight gain and excessive sweating. On examination, you note prominent supraorbital ridges, prognathism, macroglossia with thick lips, and disproportionately broad hands and feet. Visual field testing reveals decreased peripheral vision bilaterally. MRI of the brain shows a mass in the sella turcica. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is a dopamine antagonist used for the treatment of schizophrenia. Dopamine agonists, such as cabergoline, may be used as an adjunctive or second-line treatment for acromegaly but a dopamine antagonist would not be appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that has an antagonistic effect when given continuously and is used to treat prostate cancer, endometriosis, and precocious puberty. It would not be of use in the treatment of a pituitary tumor, as GnRH is released by the hypothalamus.

C) CORRECT:

Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) inhibit the release of GH and they are the pharmacotherapy of choice for acromegaly if transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is not an option. The prolonged excess of both growth hormone and IGF-1 (which is secreted from the liver in response to elevated GH) results in the overgrowth of bone, cartilage, and other connective tissues, resulting in the characteristic findings of skin thickening, enlarged jaw (macrognathia), coarse facial features, and broad hands and feet. In children, excess GH secretion results in linear growth as well, but this is not seen in adults due to the fusion of the long bone epiphyses.

Other pharmacologic options for the treatment of acromegaly include dopamine agonists such as cabergoline or GH-receptor antagonists such as pegvisomant.

Key learning point: Somatostatin analogs like octreotide are the pharmacologic treatment of choice for acromegaly when surgery is not possible.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and can be used to treat thyrotropic adenomas of the pituitary. However, this patient does not have features of elevated thyroid hormone levels, such as weight loss and diarrhea. Methimazole is not used for the treatment of acromegaly.

E) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone inhibits cortisol synthesis and is used in the treatment of Cushing disease, which may be caused by an ACTH-producing pituitary tumor and could also cause weight gain and excessive sweating. However, this patient would be expected to have other features of Cushing disease, such as hirsutism, bruisable skin, and secondary hypertension. Metyrapone is not used for the treatment of acromegaly.
questions.hint: Refractory headaches, bitemporal hemianopsia, and a mass in the sella turcica are consistent with a pituitary adenoma, which can secrete growth hormone (GH) and result in the features of acromegaly present here (e.g., prognathism, prominent supraorbital ridges, macroglossia).

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to your clinic with an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. On examination, you note enlargement of the nose, forehead, jaw, hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination reveals impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 12.5 mmol/L (4.0–6.0). Which one of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 concentration.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An elevated serum IGF-1 concentration is the most likely finding for this patient with acromegaly, a condition most commonly caused by a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Excess secretion of GH stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn stimulates cell growth and proliferation while inhibiting apoptosis. IGF-1 is part of the negative feedback cycle that governs normal GH production, so IGF-1 levels are high in response to the pathologically elevated GH levels.

IGF-1 is the most reliable indicator of acromegaly and measurement of IGF-1 levels is the first step in diagnosing patients with suspected acromegaly. Normal levels of IGF-1 rule out acromegaly as a diagnosis.

Key learning point: Acromegaly is best diagnosed by elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels, which reflect excess growth hormone activity.

B) INCORRECT:

Low insulin levels are seen in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, in which pancreatic beta cells are destroyed, resulting in persistently elevated serum glucose levels. This patient's hyperglycemia is instead due to the endocrinopathy of acromegaly, in which excess growth hormone (GH) levels stimulate gluconeogenesis, causing a state of insulin resistance. Hyperglycemia then induces compensatory hyperinsulinemia; therefore, elevated serum insulin levels would be expected in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated urine cortisol levels are a typical finding in Cushing syndrome, which is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenoma can result in bitemporal hemianopsia and Cushing syndrome can manifest with hyperglycemia. However, other features of Cushing syndrome include proximal muscle weakness, central obesity, and abdominal striae, none of which are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Low serum GH can be seen in a number of conditions, e.g., following brain surgery, severe head injury, infection, or in patients with pituitary tumors. Although this patient's clinical symptoms (headache and bitemporal hemianopsia) suggest local mass effect in the pituitary, he also presents with features of acromegaly, which is classically associated with excess serum GH.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) can result from prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas, which can also cause bitemporal hemianopsia and headache, both of which are seen here. In men, symptoms of prolactinoma typically include gynecomastia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (presenting with erectile dysfunction and loss of libido). Elevated prolactin is rarely seen in individuals with acromegaly, such as this man. In addition, he lacks classic symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, making a different finding more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acromegaly (hypertension, coarsened and enlarged features, hyperglycemia). His headache and bitemporal hemianopsia indicate local mass effect.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic because of decreased sexual arousal and erectile dysfunction. He reports 9 months of fatigue, generalized weakness, and less frequent bowel movements. He also has frequent headaches. He is 168 cm tall and weighs 89 kg; BMI is 32. His temperature is 36.5°C, pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. On examination, he has dry skin and sparse pubic hair. Neurological examination reveals delayed deep tendon reflexes. Laboratory studies show:


Sodium (Na), blood
130 mmol/L (136–146)


Chloride (Cl), blood
97 mmol/L (98–107)


Potassium (K), blood
4.5 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Bicarbonate (HCO3), blood
25 mmol/L (21–32)


Glucose, fasting, blood
5.0 mmol/L (4.0–6.0)


Thyrotropin (thyroid-stimulating hormone), blood

0.2 mIU/L (0.34–5.60)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests multiple hormonal deficiencies (although there is a considerable overlap in terms of the symptoms each hormonal deficiency can cause): constipation, dry skin, delayed deep tendon reflexes, bradycardia, and decreased TSH levels indicate secondary hypothyroidism; sparse pubic hair, and sexual dysfunction raise concern for hypogonadism; hyponatremia can result from adrenal insufficiency. In combination with headaches, these findings suggest a pituitary adenoma, which can compress the pituitary gland and lead to the destruction of hormone-producing cells (e.g., thyrotropic cells).

Pituitary hormones and the functions that depend on them are usually lost in the following order (from early to late): GH, LH/FSH, TSH, and ACTH.

Key learning point: Pituitary adenomas can cause multiple anterior pituitary hormone deficiencies by compressing and destroying hormone-producing cells, leading to symptoms of secondary hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, and adrenal insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, tuberculosis (TB) can infiltrate the pituitary or the hypothalamus, causing secondary hypothyroidism. However, except for an occasional cough, this patient lacks findings of TB such as night sweats and weight loss. Even when traveling to countries where TB is endemic, significant exposure to high-risk populations (e.g., hospital workers) is required for infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Graves disease have low TSH levels but present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism such as heat intolerance, diarrhea, and warm and moist skin. Other hallmark signs are Graves ophthalmopathy and diffuse goiter, neither of which is present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with signs of hypothyroidism, since autoantibodies gradually destroy the thyroid gland and subsequently reduce thyroid hormone levels. Reactive TSH secretion by an intact pituitary follows, resulting in elevated rather than decreased TSH levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron overload from hemochromatosis can result in pituitary damage, leading to secondary hypothyroidism. While affected individuals also have other signs of classic pituitary dysfunction such as hypogonadism, they often also present with hyperglycemia and hyperpigmentation (bronze diabetes), and joint pain (MCP II and III).
questions.hint: Decreased levels of TSH are consistent with secondary hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman with subclinical hypothyroidism comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches, loss of peripheral vision, and irregular menses. Previously, her menstrual cycles were regular every 30 days with moderate flow, but her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She also reports a recent decrease in libido. Her serum prolactin level is elevated. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and DOPA decarboxylase antagonist, which treats hypertension by decreasing sympathetic outflow to the heart, kidneys, and peripheral vasculature as well as decreasing the production of catecholamines (e.g., dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine). Dopamine normally inhibits prolactin production; therefore, methyldopa-induced suppression of dopamine production would further elevate serum prolactin levels and exacerbate the symptoms seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's subclinical hypothyroidism could progress to a manifest hypothyroidism with decreased thyroxine feedback to inhibit the hypothalamic production of TRH. TRH stimulates the secretion of TSH and prolactin. TRH-induced hyperprolactinemia can manifest as secondary amenorrhea, which is seen in this patient. However, clinical hypothyroidism would manifest with other symptoms (e.g., cold intolerance, weight gain, decreased DTR) that are not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is both a dopamine receptor and serotonin receptor antagonist that is used as an antiemetic and to treat gastroparesis and migraines. Although migraines can be associated with hormonal changes and this patient has irregular menses, her progressively worsening headaches more likely result from increased ICP caused by her prolactinoma. Prolactinoma would not be treated by metoclopramide. Moreover, because dopamine ordinarily inhibits prolactin secretion, administering metoclopramide (a dopamine receptor antagonist) would worsen this patient's hyperprolactinemia.

D) CORRECT:

Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline are the preferred pharmacotherapy for prolactinomas. These drugs act by increasing tonic dopamine signaling to inhibit lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary. This suppresses prolactin secretion and induces tumor shrinkage. Treatment for prolactinoma is indicated in cases such as this one, when the patient is symptomatic (e.g., headache, visual change, hypogonadism) or if the clinician believes that symptoms are imminent.

Key learning point: Dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine are first-line therapy for prolactinomas, as they suppress prolactin secretion and promote tumor shrinkage.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Estrogen replacement (HRT) can reduce the symptoms associated with menopause (e.g., irregular menses, worsening headaches, decreased libido). While this patient does have these symptoms, menopause would not explain her elevated serum prolactin, and estrogen is not an appropriate treatment for a prolactinoma or hyperprolactinemia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with decreased libido, secondary amenorrhea, loss of vision, and hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches suggest a prolactinoma as the etiology.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of severe headaches and reports difficulty with peripheral vision while driving. She has had irregular menstrual cycles over the past year. Physical examination shows bilateral temporal visual field defects. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows a 15-mm mass. Laboratory studies show prolactin 380 ng/mL (normal < 200 ng/mL), normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), and normal morning cortisol. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma causing mass effect symptoms. Cabergoline is the first-line dopamine agonist for prolactinomas, as it effectively reduces prolactin levels and shrinks tumor size. A prolactin level of 280 ng/mL strongly suggests a prolactinoma, and cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine due to better efficacy and fewer side effects.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone is indicated for adrenal insufficiency, but this patient has normal morning cortisol levels and no signs of hypopituitarism requiring immediate hormone replacement. The priority is treating the prolactinoma to reduce mass effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is reserved for refractory pituitary adenomas in which both medical and surgical management have been unsuccessful. Radiation therapy is not used as initial treatment due to delayed response and risk of hypopituitarism and visual complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist used for prolactinomas, but it is second-line therapy. Another treatment option has superior efficacy in reducing prolactin levels and tumor size with fewer adverse effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the first-line treatment for most secretory adenomas, but prolactinomas are managed with medical therapy first. Surgery is reserved for prolactinomas that cause acute complications or in which medical management has been unsuccessful.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of episodic frontal headaches and reports difficulty with peripheral vision when driving. She has had no nausea, vomiting, or neurological symptoms. Her menstrual periods have been irregular for the past 6 months. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows subtle bilateral temporal visual field defects on confrontation testing. Fundoscopic examination shows no papilledema. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?

choices.text: MRI of the brain with gadolinium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT of the head can identify large masses with significant mass effect but can miss smaller adenomas and provides insufficient detail of the pituitary gland structure.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- MRI of the brain with gadolinium is the gold standard imaging modality for suspected pituitary adenomas. The patient's constellation of symptoms, including bitemporal visual field defects, headaches, and menstrual irregularities, strongly suggests a pituitary macroadenoma with optic chiasm compression. Immediate imaging is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not indicated in this clinical scenario. The absence of papilledema, normal vital signs, and the specific pattern of bitemporal visual field defects point toward a structural lesion rather than elevated intracranial pressure or infectious etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine cortisol collection is used to evaluate for hypercortisolism but is not the initial diagnostic study when mass effect symptoms are present. This patient's presentation does not suggest Cushing syndrome, and imaging takes priority to evaluate the structural abnormality.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum prolactin levels are important in the hormonal evaluation of pituitary adenomas, but imaging should be performed first when patients present with clear signs of mass effect. Hormonal studies are typically done after confirming the presence of a pituitary adenoma on imaging.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with acute onset severe headache and visual changes. She reports amenorrhea and breast tenderness for several months. Physical examination shows severe bitemporal hemianopsia. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 118; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F). Laboratory studies show sodium 124 mEq/L, potassium 4.2 mEq/L, and glucose 62 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Administer IV methylprednisolone and obtain ophthalmology consultation
Obtain urgent MRI and admit for inpatient endocrinology consultation
Start IV fluids and arrange endocrinology consultation within 24 hours
Perform lumbar puncture and obtain head CT
Administer IV hydrocortisone and obtain urgent neurosurgical consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methylprednisolone is inappropriate for acute adrenal insufficiency because it lacks sufficient mineralocorticoid activity compared to hydrocortisone. Additionally, while visual symptoms are present, this patient's presentation represents a neurosurgical emergency requiring immediate specialist consultation rather than ophthalmology referral.

B) INCORRECT:

While urgent imaging is appropriate for this patient with suspected pituitary apoplexy and visual symptoms, this approach fails to address the life-threatening acute adrenal insufficiency evidenced by hypotension, tachycardia, and low cortisol levels. Rapid hydrocortisone administration can be lifesaving in acute hypopituitarism.

C) INCORRECT:

This approach inadequately addresses the acute nature of this patient's presentation. This patient has signs of acute adrenal insufficiency requiring immediate hydrocortisone, not just IV fluids. Additionally, urgent neurosurgical evaluation is indicated for this patient's visual symptoms and cranial nerve palsies, which suggest sight-threatening complications.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient's severe headache might suggest other causes, the constellation of findings, including bitemporal hemianopsia, cranial nerve palsies, and low cortisol, strongly suggests pituitary apoplexy rather than subarachnoid hemorrhage. Lumbar puncture inappropriately delays necessary treatment for acute adrenal insufficiency and urgent neurosurgical evaluation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with pituitary apoplexy, evidenced by acute severe headache, visual field defects, cranial nerve palsies, and signs of acute adrenal insufficiency. Rapid hydrocortisone administration can be lifesaving in acute hypopituitarism. Additionally, urgent neurosurgical evaluation is indicated for this patient's visual symptoms and cranial nerve palsies, which suggest sight-threatening complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of irregular menstrual cycles and milky nipple discharge. She also reports frequent headaches and blurry peripheral vision. She is not pregnant and takes no medications. Physical examination reveals a scant, non-bloody discharge from both nipples upon gentle pressure. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on further examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unilateral ptosis (eyelid drooping) can result from a third cranial nerve (oculomotor) palsy. A pituitary adenoma can cause this by extending laterally into the cavernous sinus where the nerve travels. However, this is less common than superior extension of a prolactinoma.

B) CORRECT:

Headaches and visual disturbances are symptoms of mass effect from the tumor. The pituitary gland is located in the sella turcica, directly inferior to the optic chiasm. As a pituitary macroadenoma (>1 cm) expands superiorly, it compresses the decussating nasal retinal fibers within the optic chiasm. These fibers transmit visual information from the temporal visual fields of each eye. Consequently, compression leads to bitemporal hemianopsia, which is the loss of peripheral vision in both temporal fields. This corresponds to the patient's complaint of blurry peripheral vision.

C) INCORRECT:

Facial plethora, a ruddy and congested facial appearance, is a characteristic finding in Cushing's syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol. While a pituitary adenoma can cause Cushing's disease by secreting ACTH, this patient's symptoms of galactorrhea and amenorrhea point towards hyperprolactinemia, not hypercortisolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Papilledema, or swelling of the optic disc, is a sign of increased intracranial pressure. While a very large pituitary adenoma could theoretically cause obstructive hydrocephalus leading to elevated intracranial pressure, it is not the typical mechanism of visual disturbance.

E) INCORRECT:

Widely spaced teeth, along with prognathism and enlargement of the hands and feet, are features of acromegaly. Acromegaly is caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. The patient's presentation with galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities is characteristic of a prolactinoma, not a somatotroph (GH-secreting) adenoma.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation of galactorrhea, oligomenorrhea, and headaches is classic for a prolactinoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office with a 9-month history of progressive central weight gain, fatigue, and easy bruising. She has also noted new facial hair growth and irregular menstrual cycles. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, she has facial plethora, a dorsocervical fat pad, and striae on her abdomen. Initial laboratory studies confirm hypercortisolism, and subsequent testing shows an elevated plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level. Which of the following findings is most likely to be identified on subsequent imaging?

choices.text: Diffuse, symmetric enlargement of the pituitary gland
Large, heterogeneous mass replacing the right adrenal gland
A 3-cm lipid-rich mass in the left adrenal gland
A 6-mm hypoenhancing lesion within the sella turcica
A well-circumscribed 2-cm nodule in the right mainstem bronchus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While pituitary enlargement can occur in Cushing disease, a symmetric, diffuse pattern is more characteristic of other conditions, such as pituitary hyperplasia (e.g., from primary hypothyroidism) or autoimmune hypophysitis, which do not fit this patient's clinical picture.

B) INCORRECT:

An adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare cause of Cushing syndrome. These tumors autonomously secrete cortisol, leading to suppressed ACTH levels due to negative feedback on the pituitary gland. This patient's elevated ACTH level makes a primary adrenal malignancy an unlikely cause of her hypercortisolism.

C) INCORRECT:

A cortisol-producing adrenal adenoma would cause ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. These adenomas autonomously secrete cortisol, which suppresses pituitary ACTH production via negative feedback. This patient's elevated ACTH level is inconsistent with a primary adrenal source of her hypercortisolism.

D) CORRECT:

Cushing disease is the most common cause of endogenous hypercortisolism and is characterized by a pituitary adenoma secreting excess ACTH. The elevated ACTH stimulates bilateral adrenal hyperplasia and overproduction of cortisol. Because these tumors are typically microadenomas, MRI of the pituitary with contrast is the gold-standard imaging test. The adenoma often appears as a small lesion within the pituitary gland (located in the sella turcica) that shows less contrast enhancement than the surrounding normal pituitary tissue. Transsphenoidal surgery is the first-line treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

A bronchial carcinoid tumor is a cause of ectopic ACTH production. While ectopic ACTH secretion does cause ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, it is a much less common etiology. Given that Cushing disease accounts for approximately 70% of endogenous hypercortisolism cases, another tumour is more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation and elevated plasma ACTH level indicate Cushing disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue, a 10-lb weight gain, and decreased libido. He reports feeling cold intolerant and occasionally dizzy when standing up quickly. On examination, his blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg and his heart rate is 56/min. His skin is cool and dry, and deep tendon reflexes are delayed. Laboratory studies reveal a TSH of 0.3 μIU/mL, free T4 of 0.6 ng/dL, a morning cortisol of 3 μg/dL, and a total testosterone of 150 ng/dL (normal 300-1000). Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with panhypopituitarism, a deficiency of multiple pituitary hormones. The low TSH in the setting of a low free T4 indicates secondary hypothyroidism. Similarly, the low morning cortisol suggests secondary adrenal insufficiency (insufficient ACTH), and the low testosterone points to secondary hypogonadism (insufficient LH/FSH). A non-functioning pituitary adenoma is the most common cause of panhypopituitarism in adults. The tumor exerts a mass effect on the normal pituitary tissue, compressing and destroying hormone-producing cells. Patients may also present with headaches or visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopsia) if the adenoma is large enough to compress the optic chiasm. The next step in diagnosis would be an MRI of the pituitary.

B) INCORRECT:

Addison disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, would account for the low cortisol level and symptoms like fatigue and dizziness. However, this condition would not explain the patient's secondary hypothyroidism (low TSH, low T4) or his hypogonadism (low testosterone).

C) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis is a disorder of iron overload that can cause hypopituitarism due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, particularly affecting the gonadotrophs. While it could explain the patient's hormonal deficiencies, it is a much less common cause of panhypopituitarism than a pituitary adenoma. The presentation often includes other signs such as liver disease, diabetes mellitus, or arthropathy, which are absent here.

D) INCORRECT:

Sheehan syndrome, ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland, does cause panhypopituitarism and would explain the laboratory abnormalities. However, this condition is a rare complication of severe postpartum hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

While Hashimoto thyroiditis would explain the symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, bradycardia), it is a primary thyroid disorder. In primary hypothyroidism, the thyroid gland fails, leading to a low free T4. The pituitary responds by increasing TSH production in an attempt to stimulate the failing gland, resulting in a high TSH. This patient has a low TSH, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: The TSH is low despite a low free T4. This pattern, along with deficiencies in the adrenal and gonadal axes, points to a central rather than a primary gland problem.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 9-month history of amenorrhea and bilateral milky nipple discharge. She and her partner have been attempting to conceive for the past year without success. She denies headaches or visual changes. Her medical history is unremarkable. On examination, vital signs are stable. Gentle pressure on the breasts expresses milky fluid bilaterally. Visual field testing is normal. Laboratory studies reveal a serum prolactin level of 180 ng/mL (normal <25 ng/mL) and a normal TSH. A pituitary MRI confirms a 6-mm sellar mass consistent with a microadenoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial medication for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is a somatostatin analog used primarily to treat pituitary adenomas that secrete growth hormone (acromegaly) or, less commonly, TSH. It functions by inhibiting hormone release from these specific tumor types. It would not be effective for a prolactin-secreting adenoma, as prolactin secretion is primarily regulated by dopamine, not somatostatin.

B) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine is a synthetic thyroid hormone used to treat hypothyroidism. It is a plausible consideration because primary hypothyroidism can cause elevated TRH, which can stimulate prolactin secretion. However, this patient's TSH level is normal, effectively ruling out primary hypothyroidism as the cause of her hyperprolactinemia. Therefore, levothyroxine is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

The first-line therapy for prolactinomas is a dopamine agonist, which inhibits prolactin secretion from pituitary lactotrophs. Cabergoline is the preferred agent because it has higher efficacy in normalizing prolactin levels and shrinking tumors compared to other dopamine agonists. It also has a more favorable side-effect profile and a longer half-life, allowing for more convenient once or twice-weekly dosing. Treatment aims to restore gonadal function, resolve galactorrhea, and reduce tumor size.

D) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that, with continuous use, suppresses FSH and LH secretion, inducing a state of hypogonadism. It is used for conditions like endometriosis or prostate cancer. While this patient has amenorrhea, the underlying cause is hyperprolactinemia suppressing the HPG axis, not a primary GnRH issue. Leuprolide would not address the elevated prolactin or the pituitary adenoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is also a dopamine agonist used to treat prolactinomas. While effective, it is now considered a second-line agent because it has a higher incidence of side effects like nausea and orthostatic hypotension, and requires more frequent daily dosing. It may be preferred in patients desiring pregnancy due to more extensive safety data, although a different medication is increasingly used in this setting as well.
questions.hint: This patient's amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and significantly elevated prolactin level, along with an identified pituitary microadenoma, confirm the diagnosis of a prolactinoma.
